0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-immigration-deportation-exclusive-idUSKCN0Y32J1	Exclusive: U.S. plans new wave of immigrant deportation raids	"
By Julia Edwards
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON U.S. immigration officials are planning a month-long series of raids in May and June to deport hundreds of Central American mothers and children found to have entered the country illegally
column2: according to sources and an internal document seen by Reuters.The operation would likely be the largest deportation sweep targeting immigrant families by the administration of President Barack Obama this year after a similar drive over two days in January that focused on Georgia
column3: Texas
column4: and North Carolina.Those raids
column5: which resulted in the detention of 121 people
column6: mostly women and children
column7: sparked an outcry from immigration advocates and criticism from some Democrats
column8: including the party's presidential election frontrunner Hillary Clinton.Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) has now told field offices nationwide to launch a 30-day ""surge"" of arrests focused on mothers and children who have already been told to leave the United States
column9: the document seen by Reuters said. The operation would also cover minors who have entered the country without a guardian and since turned 18 years of age
column10: the document said. Two sources confirmed the details of the plan.  The exact dates of the latest series of raids were not known and the details of the operation could change. The operation in January marked a departure for ICE
column11: part of the Department of Homeland Security
column12: from one-off deportations to high-profile raids meant to deter migrants from coming to the United States. An ICE spokeswoman said the agency does not ""confirm or deny the existence of specific ongoing or future law enforcement actions."" The spokeswoman said immigrants who arrived illegally after Jan. 1
column13: 2014 are priorities for removal.Federal resources were strained in 2014 under a wave of illegal migrants crossing the U.S.-Mexico border
column14: especially women and children fleeing violence in Honduras

column1: The planned new raids are in response to a renewed surge of illegal entries by Central American women traveling with their children. From October 2015 through March 2016
column2: the U.S. Border Patrol apprehended more than 32
column3: 000 family ""units""
column4: defined as mothers and children traveling together
column5: for crossing illegally into the United States. Over the same period in 2014-2015
column6: there were about 14
column7: 000 such apprehensions; in 2013-2014
column9: 800.(Graphic on immigration patterns of Central American migrants: tmsnrt.rs/1qglGZG)Many of those apprehended for unlawful entry are put into deportation proceedings in court but do not show up for their scheduled appearance before a judge or ignore court orders to leave the country.

column1: The surge in illegal border crossings has put Obama in a tough spot in a presidential election year in which he wants to see a fellow Democrat elected as his successor.  Obama has said criminal immigrants and those who have recently entered the country are priorities for deportation. He is regularly hammered by Republicans over the presence of more than 11 million undocumented immigrants in the country. But Hispanic-Americans tend to vote for Democrats
column2: who are more sympathetic to the plight of the undocumented.Clinton raised concerns about the January raids at the time
column3: saying they had ""sown fear and division in immigrant communities.""

column1: The presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump has pledged to build a wall along the Mexican border to prevent illegal immigration.Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson told a U.S. Senate panel in March that the January raids had helped to deter Central Americans from migrating illegally. Border Patrol reported fewer illegal entries between January and March 2016 compared to October and December 2015
column2: but there were more apprehended than over the same time period in early 2015.A separate document seen by Reuters said Johnson was concerned about the most recent uptick in border crossings. Immigration advocates say they have asked Johnson to abandon plans for future raids.""Raids are not the answer
column3: said Marielena Hincapie
column4: executive director of the National Immigration Law Center
column5: a legal aide and advocacy group for migrants.""This is a humanitarian challenge
column6: she said. (Editing by Kevin Drawbaugh and Stuart Grudgings)"	['Clinton'
column7: 'Trump'

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-cuba-us-idUSKCN0Y32HU	Cuba and U.S. officials to meet next week to deepen detente	"
By Sarah Marsh
| HAVANA
HAVANA Cuba and the United States will meet next week for a third round of talks on improving relations
column2: Havana said on Thursday
column3: adding that the two former Cold War foes were not yet negotiating their multibillion-dollar claims against one another.A bilateral commission will meet next Monday in the Cuban capital to evaluate the progress made in putting their decades-old conflict behind them
column4: and to identify new areas of cooperation
column5: said Gustavo Machin
column6: the deputy director for U.S. affairs in the Cuban foreign ministry.""We will set the agenda for the rest for the year
column7: Machin told a news conference.""We are not yet negotiating the topic of claims even if there is a recognition on both sides that these exist.""Cuba and the U.S. reestablished diplomatic relations a year ago and have signed agreements on issues of common concern such as the environment

column1: Many differences remain however. Machin reiterated Cuba's demands for the return of the Guantanamo naval base and lifting of the U.S. trade embargo.Cuba complains that some of the policy changes the U.S. has carried out
column2: such as relaxing currency restrictions against the island
column3: have had little real impact given the persistent fear among U.S. institutions of risking government sanctions.The White House said in March it would allow U.S. banks to process dollar transactions for Cuba as long as neither buyer nor seller were U.S. entities.

column1: Until now
column2: no bank transactions have been carried out in U.S. currency
column3: Machin said. ""There is still a great fear.""Cuba has said it will only lift a 10 percent tax on cash dollars once it is clear U.S. banks are processing dollar transactions for the Communist-ruled island.

column1: The issue of reparations is another sticky point. Late last year
column2: Cuba and the U.S. outlined their respective claims
column3: with the former demanding at least $121 billion in reparations for the U.S. trade embargo and other acts it describes as aggressions against the Caribbean country.The Americans meanwhile are seeking upwards of $10 billion in compensation for nationalized properties.The third bilateral commission will be led by Josefina Vidal
column4: the Cuban Foreign Ministry's chief of U.S. affairs
column5: and Kristie Kenney
column6: counselor for the U.S. State Department. (Additional Reporting by Nelson Acosta; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Nelson']	[]

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-nordic-summit-idUSKCN0Y32I4	Obama sets state dinner table for six at unusual Nordic summit	"
By Roberta Rampton
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON President Barack Obama is set to toast the five leaders of Nordic nations at a lavish state dinner at the White House on Friday
column2: an unusual summit aimed in part at sending a message to a nation not on the guest list: Russia.Obama will laud the humanitarian and environmental accomplishments of Sweden
column3: Denmark
column4: Finland
column5: Norway and Iceland
column6: but also wants to talk about how to deal with their increasingly aggressive neighbor Russia ahead of a NATO summit in July.""We share the concern of countries in the region
column7: particularly those who have a border with Russia
column8: about the increasing presence of Russian military assets in the area
column10: Obama's senior director for European affairs.""We will be discussing ways to enhance the security of the region
column12: and also what we can do through dialogue and diplomacy to urge Russia to be more transparent and to be more restrained and careful in its military exercises
column13: Kupchan told reporters.Obama last met Nordic leaders in Stockholm in 2013 on his way to a G20 summit in St. Petersburg after canceling a planned bilateral meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin because of tensions over Syria and surveillance issues.Since then
column15: prompting Nordic nations to step up their military cooperation and the United States to boost military spending to help NATO do more to try to deter Russia.During a recent visit to Europe
column16: Obama sought to reassure allies about the U.S. commitment to the continent
column17: but pushed nations to increase their defense spending and stay united amid the strain of dealing with an influx of migrants fleeing Middle East conflicts.The leaders will discuss a long-term approach for dealing with refugees
column19: as well as new contributions to the U.S.-led fight against Islamic State militants in Syria and Iraq. He declined comment on specific commitments from the meeting.

column1: 'SHADOWY SPACES'
Typically
column2: the White House rolls out the red carpet for one leader at a time. Friday will be a bit trickier
column3: juggling five guests of honor and their entourages.The state dinner itself will be in a large tent with a transparent ceiling evoking the northern lights and ""shadowy spaces in the arctic night
column4: the White House told reporters.

column1: Guests will sit at long
column2: rustic wooden tables bedecked with columns of ice
column3: fiddlehead ferns
column4: and fragrant hand-rolled beeswax candles
column5: and dine on braised Nebraska beef short ribs and salt-cured Atlantic ahi tuna served in a large ice cube. The summit is expected to be heavy on ""feel-good"" messages about the outsized role Nordic nations play in international diplomacy
column6: said Julie Smith
column7: a former Obama administration official now with the Center for a New American Security.""In many ways
column8: the actual visit is the deliverable
column10: noting it was unlikely major new initiatives would emerge.""We're at the end of the president's tenure so there are limits on what new things he can drive forward

column1: In Washington
column2: preparations for the leaders' arrival have been overshadowed by a visit by presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump to meet with congressional leaders as the race intensifies to replace Obama in the White House in the Nov. 8 election.Trump has said NATO is obsolete and European nations should look after their own defense
column3: which has sparked concern among Nordic nations
column4: said Heather Conley
column5: a former State Department official in the George W. Bush administration.""They hear with great clarity the statements of Donald Trump and they don't know exactly how this is going to work in November
column6: said Conley
column7: now with the Center for Strategic and International Studies.Norway's Prime Minister Erna Solberg plans to stress the importance of American participation in NATO for Nordic nations
column8: she said in an interview this week with the Norwegian daily Aftenposten.""With an unpredictable Russian presence in the northern areas
column9: it's important that the Americans have a focus on the Arctic regions
column10: Solberg said. (Additional reporting by Alister Doyle in Oslo; Editing by David Gregorio)"	['Doyle'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-foreign-idUSKCN0Y32MP	U.S. foreign policy veteran warns Trump would make world less stable	"
By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Donald Trump's foreign policy proposals would make the world a less stable place
column2: former Secretary of State James Baker told a U.S. Senate hearing on Thursday as the Republican presidential candidate met elsewhere with party congressional leaders.Under questioning from Republican Senator Marco Rubio
column3: a former Trump rival in the presidential race
column4: Baker said the world ""would be far less stable"" with a weaker NATO or if more countries had nuclear weapons as Trump has proposed.""We've a got a lot of problems today
column5: but we'd have a hell of a lot more if that were the case
column6: Baker told a Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing
column7: adding that U.S. commitments around the world ""promote U.S. security.""Trump met with Baker on Thursday at Trump's request
column9: who declined further comment.  The hearing
column11: was called by the committee's Republican chairman
column12: Senator Bob Corker. Corker praised a foreign policy speech Trump gave in Washington last month. Some U.S. allies worried after Trump's remarks that his invocation of an ""America first"" agenda is a threat to retreat from the world.

column1: Without naming Trump
column2: Rubio referred to the businessman-turned-candidate's suggestions that the United States should rethink the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and that Japan and South Korea should consider getting nuclear weapons to defend themselves.""Some have suggested 'why don't you just let Japan and South Korea get their own nuclear weapons and let them defend themselves?'"" Rubio asked.""The more countries that acquire nuclear weapons
column3: the more instability there is going to be in the world
column4: in my opinion
column5: Baker said.

column1: Tom Donilon
column2: Democratic President Barack Obama's former national security adviser
column3: called Rubio's question an ""important thought experiment
column4: as he backed Baker's comments about the importance of NATO.""It's not just a thought experiment
column5: it's actually been proposed
column6: Rubio said.

column1: As the hearing took place
column2: Trump was on Capitol Hill meeting with Republican congressional leaders on how to heal divisions within the party
column3: including those between establishment figures like Baker and the insurgent candidate.Baker
column4: a Republican who was secretary of state under President George Bush and Treasury secretary under President Ronald Reagan
column5: testified alongside Donilon.Former Presidents Bush and George W. Bush do not plan to endorse Trump
column6: or any candidate
column7: in this year's White House race. (Editing by Marguerita Choy and David Gregorio)"	['Corker'

column1: 4	4	http://reuters.com/article/us-health-zika-congress-options-idUSKCN0Y32GY	Senate sets votes on competing Zika funding plans	"
By Richard Cowan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Three competing plans for battling a potential Zika virus outbreak in the United States were presented on the floor of the U.S. Senate on Thursday
column2: as lawmakers tried to break an impasse pitting President Barack Obama against congressional Republicans.The first test votes on the measures
column3: which would provide at least $1.1 billion in new funds to deal with the spreading virus
column4: were expected on Tuesday.In February
column5: Obama urged Congress to quickly approve $1.9 billion in emergency funds to deal with prevention and treatment of Zika virus
column6: which the World Health Organization warns is spreading rapidly in the Americas.The disease
column7: transmitted by mosquitoes
column8: has been linked to the birth defect microcephaly and other severe brain abnormalities. It also is suspected of causing a rare neurological disorder
column10: that can result in paralysis.White House spokesman Josh Earnest welcomed ""any sort of forward momentum in Congress"" while continuing to push for the full $1.9 billion.""It could not be clearer that Congress needs to take action to help our states and our local officials fight the Zika virus. That is critical for health and safety of the American people

column1: Florida's senators
column2: Bill Nelson
column3: a Democrat
column4: and Marco Rubio
column5: a Republican
column6: called for the full $1.9 billion
column7: saying $1.1 billion was inadequate.They noted that the Florida Department of Health has reported a total of 112 Zika virus cases
column8: the most of any U.S. state
column9: as the mosquito season goes into high gear with hotter temperatures.  One proposal now before the Senate would provide Obama with his full $1.9 billion request for emergency funds. A second one would scale back Obama's request to $1.1 billion.

column1: These two options would not require spending cuts elsewhere to cover the Zika costs
column2: Senate aides said.A third one would take money from Obamacare to pay for $1.1 billion in Zika response funds.Even if the Senate approves one of these proposals
column3: its fate is uncertain in the House of Representatives
column4: where Republicans are deeply divided over new Zika funding
column5: according to aides.

column1: Two senior Republican aides said the party's House leadership has been unable to formulate a plan on Zika legislation and is preoccupied with internal party strife over Donald Trump becoming the presumptive presidential nominee
column2: as well as a deadlock over Puerto Rico debt legislation and a budget blueprint that has been stuck in the House.While plans to unveil a new Puerto Rico bill on Wednesday were canceled
column3: a third senior House Republican aide noted there is progress on that legislation and that ""discussions"" on a budget ""are moving forward as well.""   Senate backers of each amendment will try to attach their competing proposals to an unrelated spending bill the Senate started debating on Thursday.         (Reporting by Richard Cowan and Timothy Gardner; Editing by Bernard Orr)"	['Trump'
column4: 'Obama']	[]

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-warrants-idUSKCN0Y32YC	Senator Rand Paul to back bill blocking FBI hacking expansion	"
By Dustin Volz
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Kentucky Senator Rand Paul plans to become the first Republican co-sponsor of legislation to block a pending judicial rule change that would let U.S. judges issue search warrants for remote access to computers located in any jurisdiction
column2: his office told Reuters on Thursday.The bill is expected to be introduced next week. Backing from Paul
column3: a former Republican candidate for president with libertarian leanings
column4: lends bipartisan support to an effort to undo a little-noticed modification to a text governing procedural rules for the U.S. court system that civil liberties groups warn would drastically expand the FBI's hacking authority.So far
column5: that cause has largely been championed solely by Ron Wyden
column6: an Oregon Democrat and digital privacy advocate. He has vowed to work to stop the rule change on grounds it would allow the government to use one warrant to access and search thousands or millions of computers at once
column7: potentially implicating those suspected of no wrongdoing. Magistrate judges can normally only order searches within the jurisdiction of their court
column8: which is typically limited to a few counties.

column1: But last month the Supreme Court
column2: in a private vote
column3: approved the amendments to Rule 41 of the federal rules of criminal procedure
column4: which would permit judges to issue warrants in cases when a suspect uses anonymizing technology to conceal the location of his or her computer or for an investigation into a network of hacked or infected computers
column5: such as a botnot.Congress has until December 1 to pass legislation that would reject
column6: amend or postpone the changes to Rule 41. If lawmakers do nothing
column7: which is customary in these circumstances
column8: the changes automatically will take effect.The U.S. Justice Department
column9: which is pushing for the rule change
column10: has described it as a procedural tweak needed to modernize the criminal code
column11: and has said it would not permit searches that are not already legal.

column1: Alphabet Inc's Google has warned the change poses a ""monumental"" threat to the Constitution's protections against unreasonable searches and seizures. Last year Paul and Wyden worked together to force a temporary expiration of the USA Patriot Act
column2: which led to passage of surveillance reforms that pared backed the National Security Agency's controversial bulk collection of U.S. call records.

column1: Other lawmakers are also examining Rule 41. Republican Senator Mike Lee is looking at ways to address concerns
column2: a spokesman said
column3: and a small group of lawmakers in the House are weighing introduction of companion legislation
column4: sources said. (Reporting by Dustin Volz; Editing by David Gregorio)"	['Paul'
column5: 'Wyden']	[]

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-court-obamacare-idUSKCN0Y32BB	Republicans win Obamacare legal challenge
column2: add to insurer concerns	"

column1: By Lawrence Hurley
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON A U.S. judge on Thursday handed a victory to congressional Republicans who challenged President Barack Obama's signature healthcare law
column2: ruling that his administration overstepped its constitutional powers relating to government spending.U.S. District Judge Rosemary Collyer
column3: based in Washington
column4: ruled that the administration cannot spend billions of dollars in federal funds to provide subsidies under the law known as Obamacare to private insurers without the approval of Congress.At issue in the case
column5: brought by the Republican-led House of Representatives
column6: are reimbursements to insurance companies to compensate them for reductions that the law requires them to make to customers' out-of-pocket medical payments.The ruling will not have an immediate effect on the law because the judge put the decision on hold pending an expected appeal by the administration. But it adds to uncertainty over the future of Obama's signature domestic policy achievement ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential and congressional elections
column7: including whether enough health insurers will continue to participate in the program.Insurers have sustained losses from their Obamacare business
column8: saying they have not attracted enough healthy customers to offset the costs of sicker members. Two of the largest players
column10: had already said they would not offer plans in many markets next year.""If you're going to lose more money
column12: an analyst with FBR Capital Markets.Shares in hospital operators such as Community Health Systems Inc fell sharply
column13: while insurer stocks including Aetna Inc
column14: which plans to remain in at least 15 Obamacare markets next year
column16: the administration had warned that a court victory for the House Republicans would lead to a spike in insurance premiums for Americans and force the government to pay more in tax credits to insurance policy-holders.As part of an appeal
column17: the administration is likely to press its argument that the House lacks legal standing to sue.

column1: This suit represents the first time in our nation's history that Congress has been permitted to sue the executive branch over a disagreement about how to interpret a statute
column2: White House spokesman Josh Earnest told reporters.""It's unfortunate that Republicans have resorted to a taxpayer-funded lawsuit to re-fight a political fight that they keep losing
column3: Earnest added. ""They've been losing this fight for six years
column4: and they'll lose it again.""REPEATED CHALLENGES

column1: Conservatives have mounted a series of legal challenges to the Affordable Care Act since it was passed by Congress in 2010 over unified Republican opposition. Collyer was appointed to the bench by Republican former President George W. Bush.The law has helped bring insurance coverage to millions of Americans who previously had none
column2: subsidizing the cost of insurance through tax credits. In addition
column3: the federal government helped defray consumers' out-of-pocket costs.The House Republicans argued that the administration's action violated the U.S. Constitution because it is the legislative branch
column4: not the executive branch
column5: that authorizes government spending.""BIG win for the Constitution
column6: House Speaker Paul Ryan wrote on Twitter.Jonathan Turley
column7: the lawyer who spearheaded the lawsuit
column8: in a blog post called the ruling ""a resounding victory not just for Congress but for our constitutional system as a whole.""

column1: The appeals court in Washington may be more receptive to the administration's arguments
column2: in part because seven of its 11 active judges are Democratic-appointees
column3: including four picked by Obama.The case focuses on a cost-sharing provision of Obamacare that requires insurers to reduce deductibles and co-pays. Insurers are supposed to be reimbursed for these costs by the federal government. Cost-sharing is determined by the income of the policyholder and is a mechanism for reducing healthcare costs for lower-income households. The Obama administration has interpreted the provision as a type of federal spending that does not need to be explicitly authorized by Congress. The House Republicans who filed the challenge disagreed.Collyer ruled that the cost-sharing provisions cannot be funded through the same permanent appropriation that covers tax credits made available under the law.The judge rejected the administration's contention that the appropriation should be viewed as permanent because the alternative interpretation would lead to ""absurd economic
column4: fiscal and healthcare policy results.""The U.S. Supreme Court in June 2015
column5: in a ruling authored by Bush-appointed Chief Justice John Roberts
column6: rejected a conservative challenge that could have gutted Obamacare
column7: upholding nationwide tax subsidies crucial to the law. Roberts also wrote a major 2012 ruling preserving Obamacare. (Reporting by Lawrence Hurley; Additional reporting by Susan Cornwell
column9: Amrutha Penumudi and David Alexander; Editing by Michele Gershberg and Will Dunham)"	['Roberts'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-illinois-budget-idUSKCN0Y32VQ	Illinois lawmakers approve $700 million to pay social services in part	"
CHICAGO A bill to send $700 million to cash-starved social services providers breezed through the Illinois Legislature on Thursday
column2: as the state once again turned to stopgap funding measures in lieu of a budget.The measure passed the House 111-0 and the Senate 56-0. There was no immediate comment from Governor Bruce Rauner's office on whether he will sign it into law. A memo from his budget office expressed concerns that language in the bill could actually prevent funding for some programs.Democratic State Representative Greg Harris said the money would be taken from state funds outside of Illinois' general revenue fund to cover 46 percent of what the state has failed to pay service providers due to the ongoing impasse over the fiscal 2016 budget.""This is a $700 million piece of legislation that would help the neediest at the time they need help the most
column3: he said.Despite the stalemate between the Republican governor and Democrats who control the legislature
column4: about 90 percent of Illinois government is being funded through continuing appropriations
column5: the enactment of a K-12 school bill
column6: and court-ordered spending.

column1: But some parts of the government were left out in the cold. Earlier this month
column2: dozens of unpaid social service providers sued Illinois
column3: seeking more than $100 million. Andrea Durbin
column4: chairman of the Pay Now Illinois coalition that filed the lawsuit
column5: said that if enacted
column6: the bill would not end the litigation.""It could provide a downpayment of the money we are owed
column7: but it's not a comprehensive solution for the Pay Now Illinois plaintiffs

column1: In April
column2: the legislature passed and Rauner signed a $600 million stopgap funding bill for state universities
column3: community colleges
column4: and student tuition grants that covered only 34 percent of the $1.7 billion that had been earmarked for higher education spending in the fiscal year that began on July 1.Illinois is the only U.S. state without a complete fiscal 2016 budget. Rauner earlier on Thursday acknowledged that some lawmakers are working on a budget framework. That framework involves higher taxes

column6: and borrowing

column1: 9	9	http://reuters.com/article/us-nuclear-disarmament-douglas-idUSKCN0Y32PY	Michael Douglas urges Obama to think of his legacy at Hiroshima	"
By Tom Miles
| GENEVA
GENEVA Hollywood actor Michael Douglas
column2: a U.N. ""messenger for peace""
column3: wants President Barack Obama to issue a strong message against nuclear weapons when he visits Hiroshima in Japan later this month.Douglas told reporters at the United Nations in Geneva
column4: where nuclear negotiations have been stuck for 20 years
column5: that the nuclear danger was greater than during the Cold War
column6: largely due to a ""huge escalation"" in U.S.-Russia tensions and increasing recklessness in their close-quarter contacts.""There's this kind of crazy tension between U.S. and Russia. We have our issues but I don't quite see that all of this posturing is helping anybody
column7: he said.""The number of weapons that are on trigger alert is frightening. So the time for somebody to possibly make a mistake and correct it is very very short.""

column1: Douglas said he ""found religion"" in the anti-nuclear cause after the Three Mile Island nuclear accident in 1979
column2: within days of the opening of his film The China Syndrome
column3: which dealt with an emergency at a nuclear plant.  Standing beside Joseph Cirincione

column1: Cirincione said Obama had made good early progress on nuclear non-proliferation
column2: but had made only modest cuts in arsenals and was leaving $1 trillion in new nuclear contracts in the pipeline for his successor.""Every single weapon in the nuclear arsenal is now due for replacement or an upgrade. It's a looming disaster
column3: he said.

column1: Douglas
